questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a fall from her bed on her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother says that she has been inconsolable since. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Application of a soft elastic bandage or a removable splint alone may be appropriate for a different type of incomplete fracture called torus fracture, which is stable and associated with minimal to no angulation. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous pinning is not appropriate for greenstick fractures involving the distal radius because satisfactory fracture healing can be achieved by less invasive methods. Closed reduction followed by percutaneous insertion of intramedullary Kirschner wires is usually performed for mid-forearm fractures involving both the radius and the ulna, a radial neck fractures, or supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

C) INCORRECT:

Although open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) achieves perfect anatomical reduction of the fracture, it is rarely required in children because any mild deformity that persists after non-surgical treatment is eventually corrected by bone remodeling as the child grows. Pediatric fractures that almost always require open reduction and internal fixation (i.e., fractures of necessity) include lateral humeral condyle fractures, Galeazzi fractures, displaced scaphoid fractures, displaced femoral neck fractures, distal tibial epiphysis fractures, displaced talar neck fractures, and type III or IV Salter-Harris fractures.

D) CORRECT:

Immobilization with a cast is indicated for nondisplaced or only mildly displaced greenstick fractures, as in this patient. Additionally, physical activity should be restricted to enable healing. Closed reduction is required if there is significant angulation or displacement. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. After initial care, follow-up with an orthopedic surgeon is indicated to assess for complications (e.g., refracture) and to ensure complete reunion. Nondisplaced greenstick fractures usually heal without long-term complications within 4–6 weeks.
Image Description:

In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

E) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is indicated for displaced fractures or if there is significant angulation (> 10° in children aged 0–5 years). Minor angulations in pediatric fractures do not require manual reduction because they are often compensated during remodeling and growth. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. Splinting does not provide sufficient immobilization for greenstick fractures.
questions.hint: This patient fell onto her outstretched hand, which is a common cause of distal forearm fractures. The x-ray shows disruption of the distal radial cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with an intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression (concave side). This is characteristic of a greenstick fracture.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father after he fell off his bike. His father reports that his son has been learning to ride his bicycle without training wheels; he lost his balance and fell on his outstretched right hand. He was wearing a helmet and has been reporting severe pain in his right wrist since the accident. He has mild asthma and takes short-acting bronchodilators as needed. He is in the 25th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 96/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild swelling and acute tenderness to palpation of the right wrist. Range of motion is limited by pain. The radial pulse is palpable. X-rays of his right wrist are shown; they show a bulge along the dorsal side of the radial and ulnar metaphyses without significant angulation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smith fractures commonly occur after a fall on the outstretched hand, but they are complete fractures and typically manifest with volar and radial displacement of the distal fragment after forced flexion, while this patient has an incomplete fracture without displacement after falling on an extended hand.
Image Description:

Fracture of the distal radius with volar displacement of the distal radial fragment and dorsal angulation at the fracture site.

B) INCORRECT:

Salter-Harris fractures are complete fractures through the physis and most frequently occur during growth spurts in puberty, with x-ray typically showing physeal widening. This child's age and incomplete fracture with metaphyseal bulging on x-ray indicate a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

A torus fracture should be suspected in children who present with pain and swelling of the distal forearm after experiencing an axial force that causes impaction of the distal radius and/or ulna (e.g., fall on an outstretched hand, fall from a height), typically at the junction of the metaphysis and diaphysis where the bone is more porous. The periosteum in growing bones is thicker and stronger than in adults, which is why children are more prone to incomplete fractures (e.g., torus fractures, greenstick fractures). X-rays typically show mild or no angulation at the fracture site, disruption and bulging of the cortex on the side of the compressive force (concave side), and an intact convex side. Treatment consists of immobilization with a splint or a cast for 3–4 weeks.

See “Characteristics of incomplete fractures” table.
Image Description:

In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

D) INCORRECT:

Colles fractures commonly occur after a fall on the outstretched hand, but they are complete fractures and typically manifest with dorsal and radial displacement of the distal fragment. This patient, in turn, has an incomplete fracture without displacement.
Image Description:

Fracture of the distal radius with radial and dorsal displacement. Commonly a result of falling onto the extended wrist.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of falling on an outstretched hand, wrist pain, swelling, and incomplete fracture pattern are potentially consistent with a greenstick fracture. However, greenstick fractures are the result of an axial force that causes bending of the distal radius or ulna, which is not seen in this patient. X-ray typically shows some angulation and disruption of the cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression.
Image Description:

X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescent

A greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).

Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.

Red overlay: growth plate
questions.hint: This type of incomplete fracture is common in children and manifests with bulging or buckling along the metaphysis.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-hour history of ankle pain after tripping during basketball practice. He is not able to walk or put weight on his left foot. Medical history is unremarkable. He takes no medications. His mother has a history of early-onset osteoporosis. The patient appears to be in distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/68 mm Hg. Physical examination of the left lower extremity shows marked swelling of the left ankle. There is severe tenderness to palpation over the left medial malleolus. Movement of the left ankle is limited by pain. Posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses are palpable. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A plain anteroposterior x-ray of the left ankle is shown. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The distal tibial physis is responsible for a substantial portion of tibial growth until physeal closure, which typically occurs at 12–17 years of age in women and 15–20 years of age in men. Salter-Harris fractures, which most often occur at the onset of puberty or during growth spurts, can lead to premature closure of the physis, placing individuals at risk for persistent limb-length discrepancy. Premature physeal closure is more likely to occur in Salter-Harris type III and IV fractures. Salter-Harris fractures can be managed with closed reduction and immobilization for nondisplaced fractures (typically types I and II) or open reduction and internal fixation for dislocated fractures (typically types III, IV, and V).

B) INCORRECT:

Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve may occur as a result of a fracture, during surgery, or by compression at the fibular head (e.g., from a tightly applied cast or sitting cross-legged). Nerve injury at the time of fracture, however, typically occurs in lateral ankle or fibular fractures and manifests with an abnormal neurologic examination on presentation (e.g., dorsal foot paresthesia, foot drop, steppage gait). Furthermore, although this patient will require surgery and casting for his Salter-Harris type III fracture with displaced medial malleolus, the location of the fracture makes another complication more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) can occur following trauma. However, CRPS is a rare complication after an ankle injury and is most common in adults 40–50 years of age and affects women more often than men. Another complication is, therefore, much more likely in this adolescent patient with a Salter-Harris type III fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis can occur in the distal tibia following open fractures or surgery and typically manifests with a gradual onset of pain, swelling, or fever, and, eventually, progressive destruction of bone or pathological fractures. Although this patient will likely require surgery, which increases the risk for osteomyelitis, another complication is much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with a previous greenstick fracture are at risk for recurrent fractures. However, greenstick fractures typically occur in the diaphysis of the radius, ulna, or fibula after an axial force to the bone (e.g., fall on an outstretched hand). Moreover, greenstick fractures usually occur in children ≤ 10 years of age, and x-rays typically show minimal angulation with disruption and bulging of the cortex on the side of the compressive force (concave side) and an intact convex side. Recurrent fractures are not a common complication of Salter-Harris type III fractures.
Image Description:

X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescent

A greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).

Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.

Red overlay: growth plate
questions.hint: The x-ray shows a transverse fracture through the epiphysis and physis (growth plate) with dislocation of the medial malleolus, which is consistent with a Salter-Harris type III fracture.

Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

Closed reduction is indicated for displaced fractures or if there is significant angulation (> 10° in children aged 0–5 years). Minor angulations in pediatric fractures do not require manual reduction because they are often compensated during remodeling and growth. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. Splinting does not provide sufficient immobilization for greenstick fractures.

The x-ray shows disruption of the distal radial cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with an intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression (concave side). This is characteristic of a greenstick fracture.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department after falling off his bicycle onto an outstretched left arm. He complains of severe forearm pain. Examination reveals noticeable swelling and deformity midway along the left forearm, with bruising over the dorsal aspect. The radial pulse is 2+ and equal bilaterally, with no deficits in wrist or finger extension and flexion. Laboratory values are within normal limits for his age (see report).
Radiographs: Displaced mid-shaft radius fracture with volar angulation; ulna appears intact with no separate fracture lines
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Closed reduction and application of a long arm cast
Application of a removable forearm splint for two weeks
Immediate open reduction and plate fixation
Short arm cast without fracture reduction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients, displaced mid-shaft radius fractures with volar angulation require closed reduction to restore anatomical alignment and optimize function. A long arm cast immobilizes the elbow and wrist, preventing rotational or angular malalignment during healing. This approach leverages the excellent remodeling potential of growing bones while avoiding the risks of invasive procedures. Proper alignment is crucial for maintaining forearm rotation and upper extremity function, making closed reduction with casting the preferred initial management.

Key learning point: In pediatric patients with suspected forearm fractures and deformity, the appropriate management is to reduce the fracture and immobilize it with a cast to ensure proper healing.

B) INCORRECT:

A removable splint is insufficient for a displaced mid-shaft radius fracture with volar angulation, as it lacks the rigid control needed to maintain reduction. Additionally, two weeks is inadequate for healing in diaphyseal fractures. Secure immobilization with casting is essential for proper alignment and healing.

C) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and plate fixation is reserved for fractures with complications such as open wounds, vascular compromise, or irreducible deformity. In pediatric patients, closed reduction and casting are preferred due to the bone's remodeling capacity. Open surgical methods carry higher risks, including soft tissue disruption and growth plate injury, which are critical considerations in children.

D) INCORRECT:

A short arm cast without reduction is inadequate for a displaced mid-shaft radius fracture with volar angulation. This approach risks malunion and impaired forearm function due to the significant displacement. Proper alignment through reduction is necessary before immobilization to ensure optimal healing and function.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl in the emergency department who was brought in by her mother after falling from her bed onto her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother reports that she has been inconsolable since the fall. Vital signs are normal. Examination of the left forearm shows mild distal swelling. Radial pulses are strong and symmetric. An X-ray of the left forearm and wrist is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Application of a soft elastic bandage or a removable splint alone may be appropriate for a different type of incomplete fracture called torus fracture, which is stable and associated with minimal to no angulation. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous pinning is not appropriate for greenstick fractures involving the distal radius because satisfactory fracture healing can be achieved by less invasive methods. Closed reduction followed by percutaneous insertion of intramedullary Kirschner wires is usually performed for mid-forearm fractures involving both the radius and the ulna, a radial neck fractures, or supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

C) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is indicated for displaced fractures or if there is significant angulation (> 10° in children aged 0–5 years). Minor angulations in pediatric fractures do not require manual reduction because they are often compensated during remodeling and growth. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. Splinting does not provide sufficient immobilization for greenstick fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Although open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) achieves perfect anatomical reduction of the fracture, it is rarely required in children because any mild deformity that persists after non-surgical treatment is eventually corrected by bone remodeling as the child grows. Pediatric fractures that almost always require open reduction and internal fixation (i.e., fractures of necessity) include lateral humeral condyle fractures, Galeazzi fractures, displaced scaphoid fractures, displaced femoral neck fractures, distal tibial epiphysis fractures, displaced talar neck fractures, and type III or IV Salter-Harris fractures.

E) CORRECT:

Immobilization with a cast is indicated for nondisplaced or only mildly displaced greenstick fractures, as in this patient. Additionally, physical activity should be restricted to enable healing. Closed reduction is required if there is significant angulation or displacement. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. After initial care, follow-up with an orthopedic surgeon is indicated to assess for complications (e.g., refracture) and to ensure complete reunion. Nondisplaced greenstick fractures usually heal without long-term complications within 4–6 weeks.

Key learning point: Greenstick fractures in children require immobilization with a cast to prevent displacement and promote proper healing, as they are inherently unstable.
Image Description:

In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.
questions.hint: This patient fell onto her outstretched hand, which is a common cause of distal forearm fractures. The x-ray shows disruption of the distal radial cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with an intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression (concave side). This is characteristic of a greenstick fracture.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling on his outstretched left hand while playing at school. He has point tenderness over the distal radius without obvious deformity. X-rays are shown. What is the most likely fracture type?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

X-ray in a complete fracture shows a fracture line extending through both cortices. This x-ray shows cortical bulging with an intact cortex on one side, which excludes a complete fracture.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This X-ray shows a torus (buckle) fracture, which is characterized by cortical bulging on the compressed side due to impaction while the tension side remains intact. The metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction location, minimal angulation, and absence of fracture lucency extending to the physis are all characteristic features of torus fractures. These incomplete fractures occur when the bone is compressed and buckles rather than breaks completely.

C) INCORRECT:

Bowing fractures show plastic deformation with bowing or bending of the bone without cortical discontinuity or buckling, which is inconsistent with this x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Salter-Harris fractures involve the growth plate. This patient's x-ray findings are inconsistent with pathology involving the physis.

E) INCORRECT:

Greenstick fractures show cortical discontinuity on the tension side with an intact cortex on the compressed side, which is inconsistent with this x-ray.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with wrist pain after falling while rollerblading. She has point tenderness over the distal radius and limited wrist flexion. X-ray shows a fracture line extending horizontally through the growth plate with a triangular bone fragment attached to the epiphysis on the thumb side. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan to assess for intraarticular extension
Closed reduction and cast immobilization with orthopedic follow-up
Splint immobilization and discharge with primary care follow-up
Urgent orthopedic consultation for surgical intervention
MRI to further evaluate the extent of physeal injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scanning is not preferred for pediatric fractures because of radiation exposure. This patient's x-ray findings are sufficient to determine the fracture type and management approach.

B) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction and cast immobilization are appropriate for Salter-Harris type I and II fractures, which do not involve the epiphysis or joint surface. This patient's fracture pattern involves the epiphysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Simple splinting with primary care follow-up is inadequate for physeal fractures, especially those involving the epiphysis. This patient's fracture requires specialized orthopedic management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- A fracture line through the physis extending into the epiphysis indicates a Salter-Harris type III fracture. This is an intraarticular fracture that requires urgent orthopedic consultation for surgical intervention to restore joint alignment and prevent growth disturbances.

E) INCORRECT:

While MRI can help evaluate physeal injuries, this patient's fracture pattern is clearly visible on x-ray. This patient needs urgent orthopedic consultation rather than additional imaging.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents after falling from monkey bars at school. She has tenderness over the mid-radius with mild swelling. X-rays show a greenstick fracture of the mid-radius with 20° angulation on lateral view and 8° angulation on anteroposterior (AP) view. Neurovascular examination is normal. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Sling immobilization with follow-up in 1 week
Urgent orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation
Closed reduction followed by long-arm cast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sling immobilization alone provides inadequate stabilization for greenstick fractures. These fractures require rigid immobilization to prevent further displacement and ensure proper healing.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical fixation is not indicated for greenstick fractures with acceptable angulation. These fractures are typically managed conservatively with casting when angulation is within acceptable limits.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Angulation ≤ 25° on lateral view and ≤ 10° on AP view is acceptable in greenstick fractures in children aged 6–10 years. This 9-year-old patient's fracture has an angulation of 20° on lateral view and 8° on AP view, so reduction is not required.

D) INCORRECT:

Removable splints are appropriate for buckle fractures, not greenstick fractures. Greenstick fractures require more rigid immobilization with casting because of their inherent instability and potential for further displacement.

E) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction is not indicated because the angulation is within acceptable limits for this age group. The current angulation of 20° lateral and 8° AP falls below the threshold requiring reduction in a 9-year-old patient.

questions.text: A 16-year-old soccer player presents with acute left hip pain that began during a sprint. Physical examination shows point tenderness over the anterior superior iliac spine, with pain on resisted hip flexion. X-ray shows a nondisplaced avulsion fracture of the anterior superior iliac spine. The patient ambulates with significant discomfort but no neurovascular compromise. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Non-weight-bearing with graded return to activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical repair is not indicated for nondisplaced pelvic avulsion fractures without complications. Surgery is reserved for patients with significant displacement, persistent pain, nonunion, or heterotopic ossification.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Initial nonoperative management is the typical approach for pelvic avulsion fractures and includes a trial of non-weight-bearing, graded return to activity, and pain management. This conservative approach is appropriate for uncomplicated, nondisplaced fractures.

C) INCORRECT:

Full weight-bearing is inappropriate in the acute phase of pelvic avulsion fractures. Initial management should include non-weight-bearing to allow proper healing before gradual activity progression.

D) INCORRECT:

Hip spica cast immobilization is not the standard treatment for pelvic avulsion fractures. These injuries are typically managed with activity modification and gradual mobilization rather than rigid immobilization.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid injection at the fracture site is contraindicated as it can impair bone healing and increase the risk for complications. Conservative management with activity modification is the appropriate initial approach.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after a fall from his bicycle. He has pain and swelling around his right ankle with focal tenderness around the malleoli bilaterally and intact overlying skin. An x-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Urgent orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation
Immobilization in the current position and primary care follow-up in 2 weeks
Closed reduction with orthopedic follow-up in one week
Splinting with orthopedic follow-up in two weeks
Closed reduction with orthopedic consultation before discharge

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The x-ray shows a Salter-Harris Type II fracture with a transverse fracture through the physis and metaphysis. Urgent surgical intervention is reserved for Salter-Harris types III, IV, and V fractures or patients with severe displacement, not for uncomplicated type II fractures.

B) INCORRECT:

The x-ray shows a displaced fracture through the growth plate with a metaphyseal fragment, representing a Salter-Harris Type II fracture. Immobilization without reduction would be inappropriate, as proper anatomic alignment is essential to prevent growth complications. In addition, growth plate injuries require specialist referral.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The x-ray shows a Salter-Harris Type II fracture characterized by a transverse fracture through both the physis and metaphysis with a triangular metaphyseal fragment. These fractures require closed reduction if displaced, immobilization in a cast or splint, and orthopedic follow-up within one week.

D) INCORRECT:

The x-ray findings show a displaced Salter-Harris Type II fracture. While splinting may provide initial stabilization, reduction is also necessary for the displaced fragment. Additionally, for this type of fracture, orthopedic follow-up should be arranged within one week.

E) INCORRECT:

X-ray shows a Salter-Harris Type II fracture with typical features of physeal and metaphyseal involvement. Same-day orthopedic consultation is not necessary for type II fractures unless severe displacement necessitates surgery.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling off his skateboard and landing on his outstretched hand. He has joint line tenderness and swelling over the distal radius. X-ray imaging shows a transverse fracture through the physis that extends into the epiphysis and reaches the joint surface. What type of Salter-Harris fracture does this patient have?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Type III Salter-Harris fractures are characterized by transverse fractures through the physis that extend into the epiphysis and reach the joint surface. These are considered intra-articular fractures and require urgent orthopedic consultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Type I fractures are transverse fractures through the physis that separate the epiphysis from the metaphysis. They do not extend into the epiphysis or reach the joint surface as described in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Type II fractures are transverse fractures through the physis and metaphysis that often result in a metaphyseal fragment. They do not extend into the epiphysis or involve the joint surface.

D) INCORRECT:

Type V fractures are crush injuries of the physis due to compression and typically have a poor prognosis. The imaging shows a transverse fracture pattern rather than crushing.

E) INCORRECT:

Type IV fractures extend from the physis to both the epiphysis and metaphysis. While these fractures are intra-articular, they involve both the metaphysis and epiphysis, which is not described in this imaging pattern.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after falling while snowboarding. He fell on his outstretched left hand and now has wrist pain and swelling. Physical examination shows tenderness over the distal radius with no neurovascular compromise. An x-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Closed reduction followed by cast immobilization
Immediate orthopedic consultation for surgical fixation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has a buckle fracture of the distal radius, which is a stable, incomplete fracture characterized by cortical bulging on the compressed side with intact cortex on the tension side at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction. Short-arm casts are not preferred for stable buckle fractures. While casts may be used, removable splints provide similar outcomes with greater convenience and lower cost.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has a buckle fracture of the distal radius, which is a stable, incomplete fracture characterized by cortical bulging on the compressed side with intact cortex on the tension side at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction. These fractures typically result from falls on an outstretched hand in children. The appropriate management is a removable splint for 3–4 weeks. Removable splints are preferred over casts for buckle fractures because they provide similar outcomes, are more cost-effective, and offer greater convenience.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a buckle fracture of the distal radius, which is a stable, incomplete fracture characterized by cortical bulging on the compressed side with intact cortex on the tension side at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction. Closed reduction is not necessary for buckle fractures as they are stable injuries with minimal displacement. Reduction is typically indicated for unstable fractures such as displaced greenstick fractures.
